text:
I moved from a marketing manager at a startup (kinda a catch-all, but with a major focus on content marketing) to being a Creative Director, and I LOVED it. I was a writer and editor for years, but I always enjoyed working with design. In the last 5 or so years as visual content has continued to grow, overseeing content marketing provided a natural doorway to start working with designers, and soon, I found it made sense for the creative team to meet about our projects (writers, designers, SEO, an product marketer from time-to-time), and the promotion and path to Creative Directorship was seamless because of that.

As Rease has suggested, I didn’t work closely with SEO once I became a CD, but I still made a point to include any SEO experts in our process.

Creative Directors don’t write much, it’s true. But I did a lot of mentorship with writers, and I collaborated with them on important campaigns and taglines to the point where some of my lines and writing still made their way into pieces.

It was all the fun without some of the drudge work, in my opinion.

All of this to say, I think content marketers are perfectly positioned to be Creative Directors if they enjoy that type of people management, strategic thinking, and eye for design.

Happy to hop on a call if you have more specific questions!

text: Hiya - I’m a creative director for an agency, and filled a similar role for a brand. Agree totally with the folks who say that the role is mostly about people management—whether we’re talking about writers, designers, clients (including internal ones). It’s a good career move in the sense that you have a higher pay grade and you have the chance to make

text: (sorry premature send) larger change within your organization. But, you’ll do a lot less writing, so those skills get rusty.
